clinical_study.official_title: Mechanisms Underlying Spoken Language Production: Facilitating Frontal Brain Networks Following Aphasic Stroke

brief_summary.textblock:
Most of us take being able to communicate for granted. Anomia (word finding problems) after stroke can cause profound frustration and anxiety for patients and families. Some people recover; many don't. ~ 250,000 people in the UK have chronic speech and language problems post-stroke. This project will investigate how treatment for these people might be improved. The brain's speech areas can be stimulated using transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS). The kit is simple; a battery powering electrodes placed on the scalp. Healthy people who had tDCS while naming pictures could find words quicker and their speech areas responded more efficiently. How it affects aphasic stroke patients' brain function is unknown.
This project will use functional brain-imaging techniques and new, high definition tDCS with anomia treatment in aphasic stroke patients. Brain stimulation (tDCS) paired with speech rehabilitation, may accelerate speech recovery. Participants will receive three weeks of speech training - more than they may get from the NHS. Given the gap between how much time NHS therapists can spend with patients (usually ~8-10 hours) and the amount of practice required to improve, a new approach enhancing speech therapy effectiveness is desirable. The main advantages of tDCS over drugs are its focal effects on the brain. It is also safe, portable, and relatively cheap. Moreover, with backing from a UK company that leads this specialised field, the project will develop a tDCS kit that people can use at home. Patients will practise naming pictures using the kit. The research will test whether speech improves after daily practice plus brain stimulation. MRI scans will measure how speech areas respond to training. It is hoped that identifying suitable candidates and offering this treatment may reduce the number of people living with chronic speech disability.

detailed_description.textblock:
All suitable participants will be living in the community and may have already consented to previous research projects and their details identified via the UCLH Aphasia Clinic run by the CI, which will act as an NHS PIC, or via the stroke volunteer database at the Wellcome Trust Centre for Neuroimaging, run by Professor Cathy Price (Research approved by the National Hospital of Neurology and Neurosurgery and the Institute of Neurology joint ethics committee, study number: NO32.
The initial approach to potential participants for this project will be made by The Chief Investigator Dr Jenny Crinion. If the participant agrees a member of the team will discuss with them the details of the project. Patient groups may be approached directly by the CI and RAs via stroke clubs etc. All participants will be formally consented at UCL.
Healthy subjects will be recruited by the CI and RAs via the volunteer database at the WTCN or ICN, and by asking relatives/carers of the patients if they wish to be involved (more likely to be matched for age and other factors). Potential participants in research databases have already consented to be approached for further research.
Part 1: Activation and modulation of residual inferior frontal gyrus (IFG) in aphasia
Aims: to examine connectivity within regions of the brain associated with spoken word retrieval (a "domain-specific" process) and more general cognitive control ("domain-general" processing) in aphasic stroke patients.
Hypotheses: following aphasic stroke a functionally selective network core for spoken word naming (i.e. domain specific for language) lies within (i) Broca's area, in patients with brain lesions sparing Broca's area (ii) right inferior frontal gyrus, in patients with damage to Broca's area.
Experimental design and predictions:
Patients with a chronic speech and language impairment (aphasia) following stroke will be divided into those with lesions affecting Broca's area, and those whose lesions lie elsewhere. They will receive a novel type of brain stimulation, high-definition transcranial direct current stimulation (HD-tDCS, which involves placing battery-operated electrodes on the participant's scalp), or sham stimulation, while completing an object naming task (to test domain-specific processing) and a non-linguistic task which measures performance related to domain-general cognitive processing. Both tasks will have "hard" and "easy" levels which are matched for difficulty across tasks. In the naming task, difficulty will be manipulated by providing different types of cues to assist with object naming. Extensive piloting of the stimuli and procedure in both healthy participants and aphasic stroke patients will ensure that the tests are suitable for the proposed research.
Participants will complete the experiment in an MRI scanner in order to measure brain activity in the domain-specific and domain-general neural networks during the linguistic and non-linguistic tasks. Assuming that there will be more variability in performance within the aphasic stroke patients, and factoring in a 5% drop-out rate and 4% non-compliance, the study will require 60 aphasic stroke patients (30 with damage to Broca's area and 30 without) in order to be statistically powerful enough to detect an effect.
Part 2: Training induced changes following anodal-tDCS delivered to intact IFG
Aims: to test whether modulating neural activity within the IFG can enhance speech relearning and connectivity within language-specific networks of the brain.
Hypotheses: Anodal-tDCS increases the effectiveness of anomia (word-finding problems) training and modulates domain-specific (language) connectivity when delivered to (i) Broca's area, in patients with lesions sparing Broca's area (ii) right IFG, in patients with damage to Broca's area.
Experimental design and predictions:
This will be a two-arm parallel group study to compare anomia training with the addition of anodal-tDCS to anomia training with sham-tDCS in the same chronic aphasic stroke patients (n = 60) as studied in Experiment 1.
Individuals will be randomly assigned to receive anomia treatment with anodal-tDCS delivered to left Broca's area (or to right Broca's area if the left has been lesioned) or anomia treatment with sham tDCS. Researchers and patients will be blinded to the tDCS intervention (i.e. active or sham) in order to avoid bias.
The treatment block will last for three weeks, with patients completing a computer-based training task for two hours a day, 5 days each week. They will receive 20 minutes of stimulation (either active or sham), followed by 100 minutes of behavioural training alone. This will amount to a total of 30 hours of anomia training across the three week block.
Patients will complete the naming and non-naming tasks (see Experiment 1, above) before and after treatment, and the experimenters will gather additional neuropsychological and structural and functional MRI data. To ensure that performance would normally be relatively stable over time (i.e. in the absence of anomia training), these data will also be collected three weeks prior to the start of treatment (time-point 1, T1). Therefore participants will be tested a total of three times (T1, T2, and T3), with the anomia treatment block occurring between T2 and T3.
The primary outcome measures will be patients' performance on the same fMRI paradigm developed as part of Experiment 1, before and after treatment. Only a subset of the objects used in the naming test will be used in the training. This will allow a comparison to be made with improvement (accuracy and reaction times) on the non-linguistic task (on which participants receive no training between tests) for both trained and untrained items. While all patients are expected to improve on the naming tests after training, the group receiving active tDCS stimulation during the treatment block are predicted to show greater improvement relative to patients in the sham condition. These behavioural changes are predicted to correlate with effective connectivity changes within the domain specific (naming) network. Consistent with Dr Crinion's proof-of-concept study, non-naming task performance and domain-general network connectivity are not expected to change in response to the intervention.
Part 3: Establishing the relationship between frontal brain plasticity, cognitive factors, and spoken word recovery.
Aims: To integrate data from Experiments 1 and 2 to investigate individual patients' response to training. To characterise anatomical and behavioural predictors of those most likely to respond to anomia and tDCS training. Hypotheses: In the same 60 patients who complete Experiments 1 and 2, that: (i) recovery of speech is dependent upon structural plasticity of residual IFG cortices (ii) variability in anomia training response is influenced by variance in cognitive factors, i.e. good domain-general cognitive function is needed to profit maximally from anomia training.
Experimental design and predictions:
Structural brain scans plus extensive neuropsychological data will be acquired at three time-points (T1, T2, and T3 - see above), for all patients. Statistical analyses will test whether anomia training has any regional effects on grey matter density in order to make inferences about how training modulates the neural network supporting spoken word retrieval in aphasic patients. It is predicted that naming improvement will correlate with increased IFG grey matter. Furthermore, poorer naming performance before training will be associated with more pronounced improvement and greater IFG structural plasticity selectively in patients with good domain-general cognitive performance.
Summary The aphasic stroke patients will be tested at UCL at three time-points (T1, T2, and T3), each three weeks apart. At each of these time-points, participants will complete tests to determine aphasia severity and general cognitive ability, the naming and non-naming tasks (with either active or sham tDCS), and have structural and functional MRI scans. Participants will not receive any treatment or stimulation between T1 and T2, to allow the experimenters to check that participants' cognitive and language functioning is normally stable over time. Between T2 and T3, patients will receive a computer-based naming therapy, administered concurrently either with active or with sham tDCS. The testing at T3 will determine whether patients who received active tDCS show greater improvement than those who were in the sham condition, and whether the treatment is associated with any changes in functional connectivity in either domain specific or domain-general networks within the brain. Finally, neuropsychological and structural MRI data taken from each patient before and after treatment will be examined to investigate whether there are any behavioural or structural indicators which are associated with response to the treatment.
List of all data to be collected
1. Personal demographic data including: sex, age, contact details etc.
2. Clinical data including: aphasic syndrome subtype, time since onset of symptoms, past medical history, current medications, contra-indications to MRI/fMRI/tDCS, etc.
3. Language assessment scores (CAT).
4. Naming scores.
5. fMRI responses when speaking and at rest.
6. High-resolution structural MRI scans to define area and volume of infarct
7. Side-effects from stimulation/sham (Adverse Event data).
8. Amount of time spent on naming training rehabilitation therapy (recorded by programme itself - dose).
9. Consent forms. The non-functional imaging data will be recorded on a Case Report Form (CRF) kept by the CI.
Collection/Storage
Any data initially collected on paper will be transferred to electronic format. The paper data (including a copy of the consent form) is stored in a locked cabinet at the ICN which only the CI and named collaborators will have access to. The electronic data is password protected and pseudoanonymized. The CI will be the custodian of the data after the trial is completed. Data will be kept for 10 years after the completion of the study, in line with UCL policy. The functional/structural imaging data (5, 6) will be stored indefinitely at the WTCN, this will be password protected. These are extremely rich data sets and may be used in future analyses/metanalyses. Only members of the research team will have access to the data. The CI will act as custodian of the data.
Monitoring and Auditing
The Chief Investigator will ensure there are adequate quality and number of monitoring activities conducted by the study team. This will include adherence to the protocol, procedures for consenting and ensure adequate data quality. The Chief Investigator will inform the sponsor should he/she have concerns which have arisen from monitoring activities, and/or if there are problems with oversight/monitoring procedures. An independent data monitoring committee (DMC) will be set up to deal with patient safety issues related to this project. The DMC will comprise the following people: Prof. John Rothwell - noninvasive brain stimulation in stroke patients expert, Prof. Nick Ward - stroke expert, Dr Alexander Leff - stroke, neuroimaging and aphasia treatment trial expert.
The data to be monitored by the DMC will include: language outcome scores (CAT) and Adverse Event Recording Forms. All adverse events will be recorded by the CI and passed on to the DMC and will follow the UCL protocol for reporting of adverse events in a single centre trial. The main function of the committee will be to determine if there is an excess of seizures (adverse events) in either patient group. There are no plans to stop the trial early unless this is due to an excess of adverse events.

criteria.textblock:
- Inclusion criteria, subjects will be:
1. English native speakers
2. Over the age of 18
3. 12 months or more after aphasic stroke
4. Able to provide informed consent
- Exclusion criteria, subjects will not have:
1. Significant medical or psychiatric co-morbidity
2. Clinical or neuroimaging evidence of significant multifocal cerebral disease
3. Contraindications to tdcs
4. Contraindications to MRI
